title: Boy Scouts Press Ahead With Chapter 11 Bankruptcy Plan
summary: Committee for sex-abuse victims wanted judge to delay consideration of plan voting materials. The Boy Scouts of America is pushing forward with a plan to exit bankruptcy that includes nearly $1.9 billion in cash for sex-abuse survivors, overcoming advocates for some victims who sought to pause the youth group's efforts and who also want to propose their preferred compensation program.

title: The Elizabeth Holmes Trial: Jurors Hear First Patient Testimony About Theranos Blood Tests
summary: Arizona medical assistant describes the impact she felt after receiving pregnancy-test results she says were inaccurate. SAN JOSE, Calif.-An Arizona medical assistant testified Tuesday at the criminal trial of Elizabeth Holmes that she received two Theranos Inc. blood tests indicating she was miscarrying when she was in fact pregnant-results that her medical provider testified were unlike any she has ever seen in eight years of practice in women's health.

title: Cameo Adds Meet-and-Greet Option to App
summary: Fans can meet celebrities on a one-on-one basis for as long as 15 minutes on the video-sharing app. Cameo, an app where users buy customized video recordings from entertainers and other public figures, has expanded its offerings to let fans meet one-on-one with celebrities in live video calls.

title: CIOs Seek Partners in Hybrid Workplace Push
summary: Continuing their pandemic role as agents of change, CIOs are laying the groundwork for workplaces that mix remote staffers with those in the office. Chief information officers who helped spearhead their companies' digital transformations during the Covid-19 pandemic are now preparing for the next wave: A world of in-office, remote and hybrid work.

title: Why the Future at U.S. Colleges Is Female
summary: Students discuss the growing gender gap at university.. Editor's note: This Future View discusses the growing gender gap at U.S. colleges. Next week we'll ask, "Does Instagram harm its teenage users? If so, is there anything the platform can do about it?" Students should click here to submit opinions of fewer than 250 words before Sept. 28. The best responses will be published that night.

title: The Enormity of Manchin's Skinny H.R.1
summary: If you trim a bad voting bill, you end up with . . . a bad voting bill.. Democrats negotiating with Sen. Joe Manchin have drawn up a compromise voting bill. Their initial proposal, H.R.1, aimed to federalize U.S. elections, and parts of it looked unconstitutional. That bill didn't win Mr. Manchin's support, so Democrats have written what they call the Freedom to Vote Act, which they're selling as a petite H.R.1.

title: Biden, the U.N. and Afghan Women
summary: The President's gender appeals continue to diverge from reality.. President Biden's first speech as Commander in Chief to the U.N. General Assembly on Tuesday was full of the high-minded internationalist sentiment that defines his rhetoric. If only those words reflected the reality of the world he and America will have to navigate over the next four years.

title: 2022 Best Colleges in the U.S.: Harvard, Stanford, MIT Take Top Rankings
summary: Schools with the resources to deal with the fallout from Covid-19 dominated The Wall Street Journal/Times Higher Education college rankings this year. The Covid-19 pandemic has changed a lot about higher education. But some things remain constant: The top tier of the 2022 Wall Street Journal/Times Higher Education College Rankings is packed with familiar names, with Harvard University claiming the top spot for the fifth straight year.

title: Canada's Liberal Conservatives Lose
summary: The Tories offered Trudeau Lite, but voters kept the real thing.. The late British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher counseled that in politics "standing in the middle of the road is very dangerous. You get knocked down by the traffic from both sides." That's the lesson delivered to Canada's Conservative Party leader Erin O'Toole in Monday's national election.

title: Shooting Down Israel's Iron Dome
summary: Democrats pull funding for missile defenses that save civilian lives.. The Democratic Party still likes to say it supports Israel. But on Tuesday House Democrats stripped from their government funding bill the $1 billion earmarked for Israel's Iron Dome missile-defense system. Facing a revolt from progressive lawmakers, and with limited time to avert a government shutdown, Speaker Nancy Pelosi buckled.

title: Zoom Is a Verb-and a Target
summary: Challenges to Five9 deal serve as a reminder that videoconferencing star's expansion efforts won't be easy. Zoom is way too small to be considered "big tech," but the videoconferencing superstar is now facing some of the challenges better-associated with its much larger tech peers-without their advantages.

title: The Next Medicaid Blowout
summary: Democrats plan a federal program to cover childless adults. Insurers will win big but health won't.. Among the many parts of the $3.5 trillion bill Democrats are moving through Congress is a federal Medicaid program to cover mainly childless adults. Medicaid now covers 1 in 4 Americans, but Congress may soon lock even more into an expensive program with inadequate access to doctors and poor health outcomes.

title: How Much Radiation Is Too Much?
summary: Regulators have set exposure limits far too low, inspiring irrational fear of a cheap, clean energy source.. New nuclear power is cleaner and can be even cheaper than electricity generated by burning coal, but in August the U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission denied a petition aimed at reducing the cost of nuclear power and the public's fear of radiation. The petition asked the NRC to move away from its "linear no threshold" hypothesis, which has long served as the basis for its highly restrictive radiation-exposure regulations.

title: New York City Bristles Again
summary: Some think the city is a lonely place. Even after Covid, that isn't what I saw at all.. My wife and I took the train to New York from Washington earlier this month to visit our daughter, who recently moved to the Upper West Side with her 7-year-old son. We hadn't visited New York in two years. Sitting on the crowded train, I thought of Henry James, who returned to New York in 1904 after a 20-year absence. Like James, I wondered what the city would be like given all the gloom and doom about its future. After spending a week in the city, I have concluded that New York is recovering from the pandemic. To use a verb that James liked: The city bristles.

title: The Destructive Legacy of the Great Society
summary: Government subsidies for antisocial behavior stalled decades worth of black progress.. The Democrats' $3.5 trillion proposal to expand the U.S. safety net is being described as a make-or-break moment for the Biden presidency. Regarding electoral politics in the short term, that may well be true. But some of us are more concerned about what it could mean for the country beyond the next election or two.

title: NASA Reorganizing Human Spaceflight Division
summary: One new unit will focus on projects such as visiting Mars, while the other will manage commercial space activities closer to Earth. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration is splitting up its space exploration and operations division into separate units, a move the agency said will help it focus its efforts as more private companies bet on business opportunities in space.

title: Abolish the FBI
summary: How much more do we need to learn about 2016 to realize the agency is a disaster?. In ignoring the latest John Durham indictment, most of the media and official Washington are ignoring the elephant between its lines: the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: 'Praying to the West' Review: Minarets of the Americas
summary: A former atheist embarks on a journey to reclaim his Muslim heritage-and discover the diversity of Islam in the Western Hemisphere.. 'This book is about the third time I learned I was Muslim-and the first time that I decided it for myself." So writes Omar Mouallem at the beginning of "Praying to the West: How Muslims Shaped the Americas," a fascinating, occasionally exasperating and almost infallibly instructive read.

title: Gabby Petito's Death Is Likely Homicide, Coroner Says
summary: Autopsy confirms body found in Wyoming is the missing 22-year-old. A coroner confirmed that a body found in a remote part of the Bridger-Teton National Forest in Wyoming is Gabby Petito and said her death was likely a homicide.

title: Fedex Lowers Outlook, Citing Labor Costs
summary: Delivery giant reports lower quarterly profit, cuts outlook as tight labor market adds $450 million to spending. FedEx Corp. cut its financial outlook as labor shortages caused expenses to soar in the latest quarter and shipping demand unexpectedly slowed due to supply-chain disruptions.

title: Biden Urges Global Cooperation on Covid-19, Climate Change
summary: President outlines foreign-policy vision rooted in diplomacy as some U.S. alliances face strain. President Biden outlined a U.S. foreign-policy vision rooted in global alliances during his first address to the United Nations as commander-in-chief, emphasizing the importance of diplomacy at a moment when relations with some U.S. allies are strained.

title: Why Abortion Opponents Aren't Suing Texas Doctor Over New Law
summary: Physician who said he is first to violate new restrictions doesn't present appealing case for conservative groups, legal scholars say. As Texas' abortion ban was set to take effect Sept. 1, the state's largest antiabortion group implored residents to bring lawsuits against violators of the law. Since then, Texas abortion opponents have charted a more cautious course.

title: Here's How to Get the Most Out of an Older iPhone
summary: To rejuvenate your increasingly vintage model, check its battery health, free up storage and weigh your repair options. The new iPhone is here-but before you rush to buy one of the new ones, take a closer look at the one you've got.

title: Union Pressure Distorts Budget Reconciliation
summary: The penalty provisions for 'unfair labor practices' were unpopular and couldn't pass Congress on their own.. Regarding Michael Lotito and Glenn Spencer's "Congressional Democrats Are Weaponizing Federal Labor Law" (op-ed, Sept. 13): The penalty provisions unions are pushing into the budget bill would harm businesses and damp the voice of workers. That's why they are so unpopular and couldn't pass Congress on their own.

title: Biden, Milley and the Drone Strike Disaster
summary: It's time for the general to 'fade away.'. Gen. Mark Milley has had a very rough few months: the botched Afghanistan withdrawal, his cluelessness about the strength of the Taliban and weakness of the Afghan forces, and the new revelations of his communications with China without advising President Trump. The "righteous" Kabul drone strike on innocent civilians adds to a mountain of mistakes ("The Deadly Kabul Mistake," Review & Outlook, Sept. 18). While we all should honor Gen. Milley's devoted service to our country, the time has come for him to go, and, in the words of Gen. Douglas MacArthur, "just fade away."

title: What Does It Mean to Approach Dow 36000?
summary: Look out for the equity bubble's peak.. In extolling James Glassman and Kevin Hassett's 1998 prediction that the Dow Jones would reach 36000, Kenneth Rogoff omits two important considerations ("Why the Dow 36000 Forecast Was Right," op-ed, Sept. 9).

title: Carnivores and Vegans Agree: Inflation Has a Bitter Taste
summary: Good luck finding a diet that's getting less expensive.. It's often said that no battles are more fierce than the ones fought over plant-based diets. Actually no one says that but the disturbing truth is that pro-tofu and anti-tofu advocates are engaged in a bitter political clash. Perhaps cooler heads will prevail as both sides recognize their common adversary.

title: The Perils of Automated Résumé-Screening
summary: Publish the stats of how many executives and developers fail to get past their own filter.. "The Millions of Résumés Employers May Never See" (Exchange, Sept. 4) illustrates some of the limitations of the widely used automated systems for screening candidates. These call for a more thoughtful consideration of the requirements of successful employees and the metrics defining success. Organizations tend to measure what is quantifiable, which may not be representative of desired results. Less measurable characteristics such as motivation, judgment, decision-making and values are often determining factors of successful matches between employee and employer. Although judgments of these characteristics from human interaction are fallible, successful automation is highly improbable.

title: What Would Afghan Women Think of a Cricket Boycott?
summary: They are denied access to public sports.. In "A Cricket Ban Won't Hurt the Taliban" (op-ed, Sept. 14), Tunku Varadarajan writes, "In Afghanistan a theocratic minority denies political rights to everyone. Unlike in South Africa, however, no non-Taliban Afghan would want a boycott of the national cricket team."

title: Facebook Oversight Board Launches Review of Company's XCheck System
summary: Inquiry prompted by Wall Street Journal investigation into social-media giant's treatment of high-profile users. Facebook Inc.'s Oversight Board said it is reviewing the company's practice of holding high-profile users to separate sets of rules, citing apparent inconsistencies in the way the social-media giant makes decisions.

title: Swedbank Launches Search for New Compliance Chief
summary: Ingrid Harbo, its current compliance officer, has decided to retire. STOCKHOLM- Swedbank AB said Tuesday it has launched a search process to find a new chief compliance officer after its current compliance officer, Ingrid Harbo, decided to retire.

title: Google to Buy NYC Office Building for $2.1 Billion
summary: Manhattan deal is priciest sale of a U.S. office building since pandemic began. Google said it is buying a Manhattan office building for $2.1 billion, one of the clearest signals yet of big technology companies' growing appetite for office space, even as these firms embrace remote work.

title: The New York Philharmonic Returns
summary: The storied orchestra has resumed regular indoor concerts after an 18-month, Covid-19-related absence, but gets off to a rocky start..

title: 'Monsters Inside: The 24 Faces of Billy Milligan' Review: Brain Science or Bunk
summary: A docuseries on Netflix looks at the late-'70s case that hinged on the question of dissociative identity disorder, or a multiple personality diagnosis.. The multiple personalities occupying TV crime shows may not be plentiful enough to qualify for their own congressman, but they do make up a sizable constituency. And few subjects make as large a contribution to the phantom population as the subject of "Monsters Inside: The 24 Faces of Billy Milligan." Or does he? At the center of this overlong, occasionally fascinating four-part documentary series is the question of whether you can be a dangerous, sociopathic narcissist and not be harboring a boatload of stowaways inside your head.

title: A Miami Condo With 'Lime Green Walls' Gets a Color Makeover
summary: Resume Subscription. "I walked into lime green walls and a black and pink kitchen" says Eilyn Jimenez, founder and creative director of Sire design, of the 1,100-square-foot 1-bedroom 2-bath condominium her clients, a Canadian couple, had purchased in Miami.

title: Disney+ Subscriber Growth Slows Down
summary: Shares in Disney fall 4.2% after CEO Bob Chapek says streaming service faced headwinds in quarter. Subscriber growth at Walt Disney Co. 's flagship streaming service has slowed in the current quarter, Chief Executive Bob Chapek said Tuesday, a development that sent company shares falling in midday trading.

title: U.S. Stocks Finish Mixed After Global Market Selloff
summary: The Dow and S&P 500 ended down, while the Nasdaq logged a small gain. U.S. stocks ended mixed in a choppy trading session after fears about China's property sector helped fuel a broad and punishing selloff at the start of the week.

title: ConocoPhillips Bets Big on American Oil Production With $9.5 Billion Deal
summary: The company's purchase of Permian Basin assets from Shell means it will overtake all but Exxon in oil and gas output in the contiguous U.S.. ConocoPhillips is set to become the second-largest oil and gas producer in the contiguous U.S. following its $9.5 billion purchase of Royal Dutch Shell PLC's assets in the Permian Basin.

title: SEC's Gensler Doesn't See Cryptocurrencies Lasting Long
summary: Regulator says history of 'wildcat banking' in U.S. shows limited viability for private forms of money. WASHINGTON-Securities and Exchange Commission Chair Gary Gensler said Tuesday he doesn't see much long-term viability for cryptocurrencies, underscoring the importance of protecting investors in the market and bringing it under regulatory oversight.

title: CIOs Team Up With Other Executives to Counter Cyber Threats
summary: Government regulations and mounting attacks are forcing collaboration between senior staff, says Google security specialist. The rapid pace of cyberattacks and shifting government rules around how companies must respond to hacks mean chief information officers must work with other executives to effectively respond, according to one of Google's most senior security specialists.

title: Element of Change (Wednesday Crossword, September 22)
McDonald's Plans to Make Happy Meal Toys More Sustainable
summary: The fast-food chain is shifting some of its toys to plant-based materials, and the new toys will begin appearing in the U.S. in January. McDonald's Corp . said all toys included in its Happy Meals will be made from more sustainable materials by 2025 world-wide, as large companies look to make their operations more environmentally friendly.

title: This Is Better Than Butter-Whether You're Cooking Steaks or Roasting Vegetables
summary: Ghee is pure butterfat and culinary gold. Its nutty flavor and high smoke point make it super versatile as well as delicious.. IT'S HARD TO pinpoint just when ghee was invented, but the why is pretty clear. Ghee is butter that has been heated and clarified-that is, had its milk solids and water removed to produce pure butterfat. This gives it a long shelf life, a virtue in its native India where hot temperatures can quickly turn butter rancid.

title: Canadians Back Trudeau, With Reservations
summary: Liberals fall short of parliamentary majority in an election where voters weren't enamored with their options. OTTAWA-Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau fell short on his gambit of capturing a parliamentary majority in national elections and now faces demands from a left-wing rival party to shore up healthcare spending and raise taxes on the wealthy.

title: 10 Books to Read: The Best Reviews of September
summary: 'Harlem Shuffle,' 'The Master,' 'Wounding Warriors' and more of the books our reviewers highlighted this month..

title: 'The Wonder Years' Review: Aging Out of Originality
summary: ABC's reboot, narrated by Don Cheadle and starring a Black cast, is set in tumultuous, late-'60s Montgomery, Ala.. In setting up ABC's reboot of "The Wonder Years," the Narrator (Don Cheadle) provides some shorthand on his character-to-be. "Growin' up, mom and dad gave me the 'police talk,' about how to handle yourself around cops. There was a presidential election that created a racial divide. And there was a flu pandemic that they said would kill a million people around the world." Pause. "It was 1968."

title: Zoom's Nearly $15 Billion Deal for Five9 Probed by U.S. Government Over China Ties
summary: Resume Subscription. A Justice Department-led panel is investigating Zoom Video Communications Inc.'s deal to buy an American customer-service software company, citing potential national-security risks posed by the U.S. videoconferencing giant's China ties.

title: Meet Your New Interior Designer: Your Phone
summary: Many retailers-selling furniture, rugs, luxury stoves-have digital tools that let you customize a product or 'drop' it into a photo of your room.. I AM A RUG addict. The way some people like to test-drive cars, I like to roll out antique Tabrīz carpets to see how their colors and patterns might completely transform the living room...or the family room...or even the kitchen.

title: Freddie Mac Finds Home Appraisals in Black, Latino Areas More Likely to Fall Short
summary: Lower-than-expected appraisals can threaten home sales, depress property values. Homes in Black and Latino neighborhoods appraise for less than their agreed-upon purchase price more often than in white areas, according to new research from government-backed mortgage giant Freddie Mac.

title: Conoco Kicks Off Oil Industry's Carbon Shell Game
summary: Purchase of Shell's Permian oil fields heralds trend of transfers of good assets from environmentally challenged producers to those with a free hand. Royal Dutch Shell 's grain of sand is turning out to be another oil producer's pearl.

title: Apple iPhone Features Would Detect Depression, Cognitive Decline
summary: Company is working with UCLA, Biogen to see if sensitive data like facial expressions, typing metrics could signal mental-health concerns. Apple Inc. is working on technology to help diagnose depression and cognitive decline, aiming for tools that could expand the scope of its burgeoning health portfolio, according to people familiar with the matter and documents reviewed by The Wall Street Journal.

title: Apple Plans Blood-Pressure Measure, Wrist Thermometer in Watch
summary: Tech giant seeks to push past obstacles in adding health features on your wrist. Apple Inc. is working on new health-related features for its smartwatch, including a tool to tell users when their blood pressure is increasing and a thermometer to help with fertility planning, according to people familiar with the plans and internal company documents.

title: Peru's Dim Future From Shining Path
summary: Maoist revolutionary Abimael Guzmán is dead at 86, and a Marxist-Leninist is president.. It's no small irony that Abimael Guzmán-the Maoist revolutionary who founded the Peruvian terrorist organization Shining Path some 50 years ago and died on Sept. 11-lived just long enough to see a Marxist-Leninist, Pedro Castillo, assume Peru's presidency.

title: On China, We May Not Always Have Paris
summary: Europe doesn't see its interests in the Pacific as identical to America's.. After World War II, America's view of the threat posed by the Soviet Union changed rapidly and fundamentally. A comparable shift has been happening over the past few years with a rising China. Republicans and Democrats don't agree on much, but both have moved in the same direction on China. The U.S. is entering a new cold war, even if its leaders haven't quite admitted it. Many of our partners in the Indo-Pacific agree.

title: Uber Says First Adjusted Profit Possible This Quarter
summary: The ride-hailing giant would follow Lyft in reaching that milestone, which would come months earlier than Uber had projected. Uber Technologies Inc. said it could reach a measure of profitability in the current quarter, months earlier than previously expected, in what would be the ride-hailing giant's first adjusted earnings since its inception more than a decade ago.

title: iPhone 13 Review: From Mini to Pro Max
summary: Apple's latest iPhones deliver in battery life, but some promised camera and video improvements fall short. The time comes in every iPhone reviewer's life: You launch the selfie camera, look deep into your own eyes and say, "You matter. This review matters. An in-depth analysis of this hunk of Apple -branded metal and glass matters."

title: iOS 15 Is Here: The iPhone Software Update's Small Tricks Make Big Difference
summary: Apple just released the latest iOS. It doesn't bring a big visual overhaul, but new tools like weather notifications, a Focus mode and Live Text photo scanning make everyday use easier.. As an iPhone owner, you have a clear decision:

title: Spotlight Again Falls on Russia in U.K. Poisonings
summary: Court ruling into the death of former KGB agent and fresh charges in the 2018 chemical attack raise fresh questions about the Kremlin's alleged role. Russian agents were assigned to assassinate former KGB agent Alexander Litvinenko, a European court ruled, while U.K. prosecutors charged a third Russian in relation to a 2018 chemical attack in England, thrusting the Kremlin's alleged role in poisoning its opponents back into the spotlight.

title: A Nun Gave 'American Rust' Star Maura Tierney Her Introduction to Performing
summary: Resume Subscription. Maura Tierney, 56, is an actress who co-starred in TV's "ER" and "The Affair" and in the films "Primary Colors" and "Insomnia." She co-stars with Jeff Daniels in Showtime's new series "American Rust." She spoke with Marc Myers.

title: Why the NFL Wants Its Personnel to Get Covid Tests-Even When They're Vaccinated
summary: As mass mandatory testing recedes as a containment strategy, monitoring symptoms and voluntary testing is now a front line of defense.. Tennessee Titans coach Mike Vrabel woke up one August morning feeling mostly fine, but just a little bit off. His throat was sore, and his ear ached. It could have easily been explained by a long summer day at training camp barking at players.

title: U.S. Sanctions Crypto Exchange Accused of Catering to Ransomware Criminals
summary: Sanctions mark the first time the U.S. has blacklisted a cryptocurrency exchange-SUEX OTC-heralding a new approach to firms found handling illicit payments. WASHINGTON-The Biden administration blacklisted a Russian-owned cryptocurrency exchange for allegedly helping launder ransomware payments, an unprecedented action meant to deter future cyber-extortion attacks by disrupting their primary means of profit.

title: This Dairy-Free Recipe Makes the Creamiest Corn Soup
summary: This is the right way to use really good late-season corn. Onions underline the sweetness; chicken stock provides a base. That's it. The luxurious, velvety consistency comes from the corn itself.. THREE YEARS AGO, when Shaina Robbins Papach and Joe Papach moved to Madison, Wis., Ms. Robbins Papach's hometown, the couple brought with them a serious culinary pedigree. She'd earned her chops at Chez Panisse in Berkeley, Calif., and Gramercy Tavern in New York; her husband, at Gramercy Tavern, San Francisco's Quince and Napa's French Laundry, among others.

title: Universal Music IPO Gets a Standing Ovation
summary: Record label's shares jump in market debut, but enthusiasm for all music assets shows that investors have yet to refine their taste. Universal Music Group 's market debut has been a smash hit. Investors' clamor for all things musical is understandable, but risks drowning out unresolved tensions in the industry's revival.

title: Taliban Add Minorities, Technocrats to Afghan Government, but No Women
summary: Group's all-male administration still falls short of international demands for inclusive governance. KABUL-The Taliban brought some outsiders into their new Afghan government, giving positions to technocrats, businessmen and members of ethnic minorities following widespread criticism that the cabinet was composed entirely of the Islamist movement's clerics.

title: China's Regulatory Storm Risks Triggering Wider Economic Damage
summary: As Beijing tightens rules on real estate, technology and other sectors, worries grow that it could trip up growth. HONG KONG-China's high-profile crackdowns on property developers, technology firms and other private enterprises are starting to weigh on business activity and add to financial risks in the country, raising the potential that Beijing's campaigns could harm the broader economy.

title: AutoNation Taps Auto Veteran as New CEO
summary: Longtime Fiat Chrysler executive leaves Jeep maker to join car dealership; Mike Jackson to retire. AutoNation Inc. said it appointed the former head of Fiat Chrysler as its next chief executive, tapping an auto-industry veteran to steer the nation's largest publicly traded car-dealership chain out of the pandemic.

title: Buying Life Insurance? The Industry Is Being Transformed. What You Need to Know.
summary: Private-equity firms and other asset managers are increasingly buying into insurance and annuities. A growing number of U.S. life insurers-small, midsize and some of the industry's biggest household names-have sold or announced they will sell their U.S. consumer life-insurance and annuity businesses.

title: Who Owns Your Life Insurance Policy? It Might Be a Private-Equity Firm
summary: Resume Subscription. Americans own more than 160 million individual life insurance and annuity policies. A big, unexpected change is ahead for many of them.

title: Everything You've Learned From Movies About Fire Sprinklers Is Wrong (Except 'Die Hard')
summary: Film scenes provide inspiration for a man on a quest to increase fire-sprinkler awareness; 'It's always a little exciting to find another example'. Other people may have been watching Alexandra Daddario in her performance as an unhappy honeymooner on HBO's series "The White Lotus." Patrick Smith was paying closer attention to a scene Ms. Daddario has in the new indie movie "Die in a Gunfight," where she smooches with co-star Diego Boneta in a diner booth.

title: A Kushner's Castle
summary: Inside the Puck Penthouses home Joshua Kushner and Karlie Kloss are listing for $23.5 million.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Joshua Kushner, Karlie Kloss List New York Penthouse for $23.5 Million
summary: The couple recently agreed to buy the building's top unit, which had been asking $42.5 million. After striking a deal to buy the top unit at the Puck Penthouses in New York City, Joshua Kushner and Karlie Kloss are listing a smaller unit in the building for $23.5 million.

title: What China Must Do to Contain Evergrande Fallout
summary: Biggest risk to China is from Evergrande's small creditors, not its large ones. China's second-largest real-estate developer by revenue-with liabilities equal to around 2% of the country's gross domestic product-is in danger of going under. After weeks of ignoring Evergrande 's wobbles, on Monday Wall Street finally stood up and listened: the S&P 500 dropped 2% and global bond funds, some of them invested heavily in Chinese developers' dollar debt, retreated. Evergrande must pay $83.5 million in bond interest on Thursday, and is fending off protests and court cases from its domestic suppliers, customers and investors.

title: U.S. and China Avert Potential Clash in U.N. Over Myanmar Representation
summary: Compromise means envoy of deposed civilian government won't speak at U.N. meeting, but leaves issue of Myanmar's international representation unresolved. Myanmar's permanent representative to the United Nations, a holdover from the country's deposed civilian government, will sit out a series of high-level meetings in New York this week, averting for now a potential clash between the U.S. and China over who should represent the country on the world stage.

title: Evergrande Is China's Economy in a Nutshell
summary: China's economic model has run out of road, and the process of putting it on a new track is likely to bring more Evergrande-like mistakes. Teetering Shenzhen property conglomerate China Evergrande is the Chinese economy in miniature. Both have operated for decades on the principle that it was worth borrowing to build, in Evergrande's case mostly housing, in China's case not just apartments, but roads, rail, airports and other infrastructure.

title: U.S. Bancorp to Buy MUFG Union Bank for About $8 Billion
summary: Deal boosts U.S. Bank's presence in California and other parts of the West Coast. U.S. Bancorp said it agreed to buy MUFG Union Bank's core retail banking operations in an $8 billion cash-and-stock deal meant to boost the Minneapolis-based bank's presence on the West Coast.

title: The Covid-19 Pandemic Put Many Pregnancy Plans on Hold. Some Women Aren't Waiting Anymore.
summary: Most Popular News. On a Thursday morning in May, Kristyn Hodgdon entered a doctor's office and laid eyes on the nitrogen tank containing the embryos that might one day become her babies.

title: U.S. Lifts Travel Ban Just as Europe Takes Flight Again
summary: Airlines in Europe are coming off a strong summer of vacation flying and prospects for trans-Atlantic flights could offer a fresh boost. LONDON-The U.S. is opening its borders to foreign air travelers just as Europe is starting to fly again, promising a fresh boost for an industry hard-hit by Covid-19.

title: Fed Faces Calls to Remove Officials Over Trades They Made While Setting Policy
summary: Lobby groups Better Markets and Fed Up say Dallas Fed leader Robert Kaplan and Boston Fed leader should lose their jobs. Two advocacy groups said two senior Federal Reserve officials who traded stocks and other investments while setting monetary policy should lose their jobs, while a former senior Fed adviser said one of the men should be fired and the other should take leave pending an investigation.

title: Trudeau Headed for Election Victory but No Majority
summary: Incumbent's bid for stronger mandate set to fall short forcing Liberal Party to rely on other parties to implement its agenda. OTTAWA-Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau was headed toward a third straight electoral victory Tuesday morning, although his bet that a snap vote would help him secure a majority government failed to materialize.

title: Children's Covid-19 Vaccine Gets Closer, Bringing a Mix of Relief and Worry
summary: Many parents of vaccine-ineligible children have been holding their breath as schools resume and pediatric cases rise. Monday's announcement that a Covid-19 vaccine for children is drawing nearer hit many parents as the first truly good news in months.

title: Men Pay a Higher Price Than Women When a Workplace Joke Falls Flat
summary: A study finds that women are seen as more likeable and competent than men after similar failed attempts at humor. When jokes fail, do people think worse of the person who told them?

title: Banks Oppose Strict Basel Rules Targeting Cryptocurrencies
summary: Forum for lenders including JPMorgan and Deutsche Bank argues rules would push crypto trading into unregulated corners of the financial system. The biggest U.S. and European banks oppose strict new rules that would require them to set aside a dollar in capital for every dollar of bitcoin they own, a group of trade associations representing the lenders told the top global standard setter for banking regulation.

title: The Latest Dodgers-Giants Rivalry: To Avoid the Wild-Card Game
summary: Due to the quirks of MLB's postseason structure, whichever team loses the NL West battle will have to play in a do-or-die elimination game. The two best teams in baseball are the San Francisco Giants and Los Angeles Dodgers. That's been clear all summer, and it's even more obvious now when there are two weeks left in the season and they're both on pace to win about 104 games. It would be the first time two clubs in the same league finished with that many victories since 1942.

title: Uber, U.S. Bancorp, Lennar: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: Futures suggest Wall Street indexes could claw back some losses after tumbling on Monday. U.S. stock futures are up, suggesting markets are poised to rebound a day after concerns about China's property sector helped fuel a global selloff in stocks and commodities. Here's what we're watching ahead of Tuesday's open.

title: Jonathan Franzen, With Mom in Mind, Softens His Edge
summary: The bestselling novelist talks about his latest book, 'Crossroads,' and taking a more compassionate stance toward his characters-and himself.. Jonathan Franzen's mother knew how to wound him in just the right way. "It requires a high level of subtlety," says the 62-year-old novelist from his home in Santa Cruz, California. "You must have observed the person carefully and you must have identified what's likely to hurt the most, and then there's the rhetorical challenge of delivering the painful blow without having your fingerprints on it," he says. A homemaker who died of cancer in 1999, his mother, Irene, continues to be influential in the author's life. The anger he's long harbored, manifested in everything from his self-admitted road rage to his vocal hatred of social media, informed his five previous novels, from his 1988 debut, The Twenty-Seventh City, to 2015's Purity, he says.

title: Fortune Appoints Insider's Alyson Shontell as Top Editor
summary: Digital-media veteran plans to focus on increasing business magazine's online readership and subscriptions. Fortune hired digital-media veteran Alyson Shontell as its next top editor, in a bid to expand the business magazine's online readership and revenue as its print business fades.

title: Daniel Kahneman: How Companies Can Improve Their Hiring Process
summary: The Nobel Prize winner says employers should ask the same questions of every applicant. As a young lieutenant, Daniel Kahneman was asked to improve the Israeli army's haphazard process of assessing capabilities among combat-eligible recruits.

title: Hines, Korean Pension Fund Bet Big on San Francisco Comeback
summary: They plan to redevelop site of PG&E's office campus in San Francisco. Real-estate developer Hines Interests LP and a South Korean pension fund are planning a $2.5 billion-plus office and apartment project in San Francisco, a vote of confidence in one of the markets most upended by the pandemic.

title: Texas Abortion Law Faces Pushback From Some Companies
summary: Lyft, Box, Stitch Fix among dozens of companies to sign statement; some large Texas employers declined to sign. Dozens of businesses are going public with their opposition to a new Texas law that bars abortion after about six weeks of pregnancy, a move that follows weeks of debate inside companies about how to respond.

title: Flying Taxis' Best Ride Is to the Helicopter Market
summary: Helicopter operator Bristow has just preordered up to 50 vehicles from British startup Vertical Aerospace. Cabdrivers don't need to worry about being replaced by flying cars. Helicopter makers might need to a little bit.

title: Private-Equity Firms Start Exploring the Space Sector
summary: The fast-growing industry is beginning to attract the attention of buyout firms. Private-equity firms are ramping up investment in the booming space sector, with some aiming to plant flags in an industry where buyout shops haven't previously been major players.

title: Universal Music Shares Soar in Market Debut
summary: Shares in world's largest music company jump almost 40%. Shares of Universal Music Group NV-the music giant behind stars including Taylor Swift, Drake and the Beatles-surged in their trading debut, representing a strong vote of confidence among investors in a resurgent music industry.

title: J&J Says Covid-19 Vaccine Booster Two Months After First Shot Increases Protection
summary: Trial participants in the U.S. who received a second dose eight weeks after the first had 94% protection against the illness. Johnson & Johnson said a booster dose of its Covid-19 vaccine administered two months after the first shot increased protection against symptomatic illness in trial participants, as federal regulators evaluate data for the country's strategy for rolling out boosters.

title: Delta Set to Slow but Not Derail Global Economic Recovery
summary: OECD cuts growth forecast for this year but raises projections for 2022. The fast-spreading Delta variant of Covid-19 has slowed the pace of the global economic recovery but won't derail it, according to new forecasts released by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

title: Developer China Evergrande's 'Darkest Moment' Will Pass, Boss Tells Staff
summary: China's most indebted property developer is on the brink of failure after years of rapid expansion and aggressive borrowing. The boss of beleaguered China Evergrande Group said he expects the developer to emerge soon from what he called its "darkest moment" and pledged to deliver the homes it has promised to buyers and other stakeholders.

title: Digital Freight Startup Transfix Going Public in SPAC Deal
summary: Merger with a blank-check company is the latest in a series of deals shaking up the freight logistics sector. Transfix Inc. plans to go public through a merger with a special-purpose acquisition company, giving the digital freight startup an enterprise value of $1.1 billion in the latest deal shaking up the middleman freight brokerage business.

title: Credit Suisse's Archegos Disaster Exposes Cracks in Bank Regulation
summary: Trades routed through London weren't in the scope of Federal Reserve stress tests of Credit Suisse's U.S. trading arm this year. When Archegos Capital Management blew up, it saddled Credit Suisse Group AG with $5.5 billion in losses. One reason investors and regulators were blindsided: a gap in the regulatory oversight of big international banks.

title: Startup Firms Help Home Buyers Win Bidding Wars With All-Cash Offers
summary: Some companies front buyers the cash to buy homes outright; others buy houses directly on a buyer's behalf and then sell them to the buyer. When Nestor and Tracy Eugenio decided to move to northern California, they worried about landing a home in such a competitive market. The Eugenios planned to take out a mortgage, which is often a disadvantage when pitted against all-cash buyers who can close quickly.

title: Retailers Navigate Freight Costs, Scarce Inventory and Uncertain Future
summary: Despite rosy earnings outlooks, finance chiefs warn of myriad challenges for at least another year. Finance executives in the retail industry continue to face a multitude of challenges as they plan for the fall and the holiday season despite being generally optimistic on their companies' earnings outlook.

title: Powell's Taper Tightrope Could Be Complicated by Fed 'Dots'
summary: Fed has tried to decouple a coming reduction in asset purchases from signaling its rate plans, but new projections could pose an obstacle. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell faces the risk of another dot dilemma this week.

title: Billions Spent on Roads, Transit Projects Are Often Based on Optimistic Forecasts
summary: Ridership projections can be used to justify expenditures on infrastructure. Transportation planners are looking for ways to improve their travel forecasts as Congress debates spending billions of dollars on new projects.

title: Why Container Ships Can't Avoid the California Logjam
summary: The armada of vessels waiting offshore keeps growing, and experts say there are few viable alternatives to the country's main gateway for Asian imports. There appears to be no sailing around the breathtaking backup of container ships off the jammed ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach.

title: U.S. Pledge to Vaccinate Poor Nations Stumbles Amid Logistical Hurdles
summary: Lack of infrastructure, resources present problems as Biden administration prepares to call for more global aid at U.N. General Assembly. A White House plan to donate hundreds of millions of doses of Covid-19 vaccines has been hampered in many developing countries by a lack of infrastructure to handle storage and distribution, leaving poorer nations far behind the developed world in vaccination rates.

title: U.S. Stock-Market Tumble Hasn't Quelled Optimism
summary: Many traders continue to be bullish on stocks, even as sentiment surveys show growing pessimism. U.S. stocks are facing their most uncertain outlook since the Covid-19 pandemic sent the market tumbling last year. But many investors say there is no better place to be right now.

title: New Hires Can Spread Mental-Health Problems to Their Co-Workers
summary: A study found that when troubled workers go to new firms, they often raise the company's level of anxiety, depression and stress. Can people spread mental-health problems from one company to another like an infectious disease?

title: College and Covid: Students Talk About Their Experiences in the Pandemic
summary: They say they missed a lot-academically and socially-when classes moved online. The world opens up to students during college. So what happens when a pandemic shuts it down? We asked five college students to tell us about the impact of Covid-19 on their college experience. Here's what they said.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: U.S. Flies Haitian Migrants Home in Bid to Manage Border Crisis
summary: As authorities attempt to regain control of border where migrants crossed freely, Haitians start arriving in a country they left years ago. DEL RIO, Texas-The Biden administration has begun sending many of the approximately 16,000 migrants who have overwhelmed this small city in recent days to their home country of Haiti, including some who haven't lived in the impoverished island nation for years.

title: Democrats Add Debt Limit to Spending Measure, Sparking Showdown With GOP
summary: House is expected to vote on the combined measure this week to prevent both a partial government shutdown and a potential default on U.S. debt. WASHINGTON-Democratic leaders said Monday they would attach a suspension of the debt limit through December 2022 to a short-term spending bill, setting up a clash with Republicans over preventing both a partial government shutdown and a potential default on U.S. debt.

title: Texas Doctor Who Performed Abortion Is Sued in Test of New Law
summary: Arkansas man says he sued in hopes of collecting $10,000 or challenging the law; other suit is filed by Illinois man described as 'pro choice plaintiff'. AUSTIN, Texas-A Texas doctor who publicly said he performed an abortion was sued Monday in state court by two different plaintiffs, handing Texas the first tests of its new abortion law.

title: U.N. Climate Talks at Risk, Secretary-General Says
summary: Secretary-General Guterres says drastic action needed to meet emission cuts agreed to in 2015 Paris accord. NEW YORK-The coming climate summit in Glasgow, Scotland, runs a "high risk of failure" unless world leaders take stronger measures to stem greenhouse-gas emissions, United Nations Secretary-General António Guterres said Monday.
